preparation: Tea or topical oil
tradition_notes: Used for tension-type headache and digestive discomfort in parts of Europe.
cautions: Topical menthol can irritate skin; oils may aggravate reflux.

preparation: Decoction (bark tea)
tradition_notes: Historically used for fever and pain due to salicylates.
cautions: Avoid if aspirin-sensitive; bleeding risk; pediatric caution.

preparation: Herbal tea
tradition_notes: Sweat-inducing tea traditionally used for colds/fever.
cautions: Possible Asteraceae allergy; avoid large amounts in pregnancy.

preparation: Leaf infusion
tradition_notes: Used in Ayurveda/folk practice for fever and skin issues.
cautions: Potential liver/renal risks in high doses; avoid in pregnancy.

preparation: Tea with honey
tradition_notes: Common home remedy for cough in Mediterranean households.
cautions: Thyme oil can be irritating; tea generally mild.

preparation: Decoction
tradition_notes: Soothing throat teas and decoctions.
cautions: Excess can raise blood pressure; drug interactions (glycyrrhizin).

preparation: Fresh root tea
tradition_notes: Widely used for mild nausea and digestion support.
cautions: May affect anticoagulants; heartburn in some.

preparation: Herbal tea
tradition_notes: Mint tea as a common household remedy for upset stomach.
cautions: Can aggravate reflux; watch for allergies.

preparation: Leaf tea
tradition_notes: Astringent leaf teas used for diarrhea in folk medicine.
cautions: Tannins may irritate; hydration and ORS are key.

preparation: Boiled rice water
tradition_notes: Simple home preparation to support hydration.
cautions: Not a substitute for oral rehydration therapy when needed.

preparation: Gargle/Tea
tradition_notes: Warm sage gargles/teas as a home remedy.
cautions: Avoid ingesting concentrated essential oil.

preparation: Warm saltwater gargle
tradition_notes: Common home remedy to soothe irritation.
cautions: Do not swallow excessive salt; hydrate.

preparation: Tea/chew seeds
tradition_notes: Post-meal seed teas for gas/bloating.
cautions: Essential oils can irritate; seeds typically mild.

preparation: Tea/Tincture
tradition_notes: Traditionally used at cold onset.
cautions: Allergic reactions possible; evidence mixed.

preparation: Syrup/Tea
tradition_notes: Home-made syrups/teas in some regions.
cautions: Unripe/raw parts can be toxic; cook thoroughly.

preparation: Topical paste
tradition_notes: Applied for minor skin issues in folk practice.
cautions: Topical sensitivity; staining; not for deep/open wounds.

preparation: Fresh gel
tradition_notes: Household gel for minor sunburns/irritation.
cautions: Allergy possible; not for severe burns.

preparation: Tea/Extract
tradition_notes: Bedtime tea/extract for sleep in folk use.
cautions: Drowsiness; interactions with sedatives possible.

preparation: Tea
tradition_notes: Calming tea; used for mild cramping and sleep.
cautions: Asteraceae allergy; anticoagulant interaction possible.

preparation: Seed tea
tradition_notes: Spice tea used for cramps in some traditions.
cautions: May affect blood sugar; avoid in pregnancy unless advised.

preparation: Topical 10% peppermint oil in ethanol; dab on temples/forehead up to 3×/day; keep away from eyes; short-term use only.
tradition_notes: Common OTC in Germany for tension-type headache; long-standing European use.
cautions: Topical only on intact skin; avoid in infants; may irritate skin; keep away from eyes.

preparation: Tea or standardized dry extract per product label for short-term lower back pain.
tradition_notes: European traditional analgesic (salicylates).
cautions: Avoid with salicylate allergy, anticoagulants, or GI ulcer; drug interactions.

preparation: 1 g/day dried ginger in divided doses (capsules or tea) for motion sickness or pregnancy nausea; follow product label.
tradition_notes: Widely used across South Asia; also global.
cautions: May cause GI upset; caution in pregnancy if high doses; consult clinician.

preparation: Infusion: 1–2 g herb in 150 ml hot water, 3–4×/day; or per product label.
tradition_notes: Used in Levant (za’atar/thyme infusions) and across Europe for coughs.
cautions: Essential oils can irritate if concentrated; follow label.

preparation: Standardized extract (e.g., EPs 7630) per label for up to ~7–10 days.
tradition_notes: Origin in Southern African traditional medicine; used globally for colds/bronchitis.
cautions: Possible GI upset; rare liver issues reported; avoid if liver disease; drug interactions possible.

preparation: 1–2 tsp honey in warm water/tea as needed (adults & children ≥1 year).
tradition_notes: Common remedy across cultures; CDC includes for cough relief.
cautions: Do NOT give to infants <12 months (botulism risk); caution with diabetes.

preparation: Gargle: ~0.5 ml fluid extract in 150 ml warm water, up to 3×/day.
tradition_notes: Mediterranean/European tradition; HMPC posology lists gargle.
cautions: Avoid during pregnancy in high doses; essential oil not for internal use.

preparation: ½ tsp salt in a glass of warm water; gargle and spit; repeat as needed (adults).
tradition_notes: NHS-recommended self-care.
cautions: Not for young children due to choking risk; do not swallow.

preparation: Infusion: 2–3 g in 150 ml water, 3–4×/day; or per label.
tradition_notes: Widespread in North Africa/Europe for GI spasm and bloating.
cautions: Allergy possible (Asteraceae).

preparation: Tea: equal parts crushed fruits (~1–2 g total) infused; or use licensed combo products.
tradition_notes: Very common after meals in Turkey/Germany.
cautions: Estragole exposure caution with fennel oils; avoid in biliary disorders.

preparation: Standardized dry extract per label; single dose ½–1 h before bedtime.
tradition_notes: Centuries of European use for sleep.
cautions: May cause drowsiness; GI upset; avoid with other sedatives.

preparation: Tea (1.5–4 g/150 ml) 3–4×/day for stress; evenings for sleep.
tradition_notes: Central/Eastern Europe calming herb.
cautions: May cause sedation; caution with thyroid issues (rare reports).

preparation: Decoction/tea from leaves or standardized extract with oral rehydration; follow study/product protocols.
tradition_notes: Traditional across Mexico/Philippines; studied for infectious diarrhea.
cautions: Does NOT replace ORS/medical care; evidence mixed; possible interactions.

preparation: Cool burn with water, then apply plain aloe gel topically.
tradition_notes: Common across tropics; also in Mexico.
cautions: Topical ok; oral latex is unsafe; allergy possible.

preparation: Steam inhalation with a few drops of oil; or licensed inhalation products; follow label.
tradition_notes: Traditional in Australia; widely used globally.
cautions: Do not use undiluted on skin; keep away from children; avoid ingestion.

preparation: Infusion at onset of cold symptoms.
tradition_notes: Central/Eastern European tradition.
cautions: Allergy possible.

preparation: Infusion: 1–1.5 g dried flowers in hot water, several times daily (strain well).
tradition_notes: Used in Iberian folk medicine; demulcent.
cautions: Pollen hairs can irritate—strain; avoid if allergic.

preparation: Tea or lozenges per label for throat/cough soothing.
tradition_notes: West/Central Asian and Chinese traditional use.
cautions: Avoid in pregnancy; can raise blood pressure/low potassium; interactions (e.g., diuretics).

preparation: Standardized leaf extract syrup/drops per label for chesty/productive cough.
tradition_notes: Widely used expectorant in Germany; helps loosen mucus.
cautions: Observe dose on licensed products; GI upset possible.

preparation: Tea or standardized extract for mild stress/insomnia; evening use.
tradition_notes: Traditional in South America; used as a calming herb.
cautions: May cause drowsiness; avoid combining with sedatives.

preparation: Topical preparations (ointments/washes) for minor skin inflammation and wounds.
tradition_notes: European and Latin American folk use; topical soothing.
cautions: Allergy possible (Asteraceae).

preparation: Short-term astringent tea/wash for mild, non-specific diarrhea.
tradition_notes: Traditional astringent in Northern/Central Europe.
cautions: Short-term use only; constipation possible; not for long courses.

preparation: Standardized extract at onset of URTI symptoms per product label.
tradition_notes: Used in Southeast Asia; some trials report shorter symptom duration.
cautions: GI upset/headache possible; avoid in pregnancy.

preparation: Syrup/tablets from standardized extracts for cough/bronchitis per label.
tradition_notes: Approved traditional medicine in the Philippines (Lagundi).
cautions: Mild GI upset possible; follow licensed-product dosing.

preparation: Low-dose capsaicin cream/patch applied to painful area per label.
tradition_notes: Counter-irritant from chili pepper; some trials support topical use.
cautions: Burning sensation common at start; avoid broken skin/eyes.

preparation: Demulcent lozenges/tea for dry cough or throat irritation.
tradition_notes: Traditional in Nordic countries; soothing mucilage.
cautions: Generally well tolerated; ensure adequate fluids.

preparation: Steam inhalation with a few drops of oil; or licensed inhalation products.
tradition_notes: Introduced and cultivated in Chile; used for congestion/inhalation.
cautions: Essential oil not for ingestion; keep from children; avoid undiluted skin use.

preparation: Leaf decoction or standardized extract alongside oral rehydration.
tradition_notes: Common in Brazil and across the tropics; studied for infectious diarrhea.
cautions: Does not replace ORS/medical care; interactions possible.

preparation: Standardized preparations for migraine prophylaxis (not acute attack).
tradition_notes: Traditional European herb; clinical results mixed.
cautions: Not for pregnancy; possible mouth ulcers with fresh leaves.

preparation: Powder/capsules ~750–2000 mg/day during first days of menses, per study/product.
tradition_notes: Used for dysmenorrhea; several small RCTs show benefit.
cautions: May cause heartburn; interacts with anticoagulants.

preparation: Tea after meals for gas/spasm; enteric-coated oil for IBS per label.
tradition_notes: Mint tea widely consumed; antispasmodic effects documented.
cautions: May worsen reflux; caution with GERD.

preparation: 1–2 tsp in warm water/tea as needed (adults/children ≥1 year).
tradition_notes: Honey preparations commonly used for throat comfort; evidence mixed.
cautions: Never give honey to infants <12 months (botulism risk).

preparation: Mild tea sipped for nausea/indigestion.
tradition_notes: Common household herbal tea across Central/Eastern Europe.
cautions: Allergy possible (Asteraceae).

preparation: Caffeine-free infusion after meals for gentle digestion.
tradition_notes: Traditional South African tea; low tannins make it easy on the stomach.
cautions: Generally well tolerated; avoid very hot beverages.

preparation: Hot infusion taken during febrile colds.
tradition_notes: Common household tea for fever and colds in Ghana and neighboring countries.
cautions: Essential oils can irritate if concentrated; tea is milder.

preparation: Reconstituted pulp drink with safe water, alongside oral rehydration salts (ORS).
tradition_notes: Baobab pulp beverage traditionally given for diarrhea and rehydration support.
cautions: Does not replace ORS or medical care; watch added sugar.

preparation: Hot infusion; optionally with honey and lime.
tradition_notes: Widely used across Nigeria for coughs and catarrh.
cautions: Essential-oil rich; may irritate in high doses.

preparation: Warm sour tea (karkadé) sipped to soothe the throat.
tradition_notes: Popular across the Sahel and West Africa; soothing beverage.
cautions: "May affect blood pressure in high amounts; acidic on teeth."

preparation: Evening tea for relaxation and mild sleeplessness.
tradition_notes: Sahelian shrub used as a calming tea (kinkeliba).
cautions: Evidence limited; mild diuretic effect reported.

preparation: Cool burn with water, then apply plain gel topically.
tradition_notes: Traditional use similar to Aloe vera for superficial burns.
cautions: Allergy possible; not for deep or infected burns.

preparation: Thin layer on clean, superficial skin to moisturize and protect.
tradition_notes: Common West African emollient used on minor dry skin and superficial abrasions.
cautions: Possible nut/seed allergy; do not apply to deep wounds.

preparation: Lightly crushed seeds steeped as tea after meals.
tradition_notes: Spice tea used for digestion and mild nausea from Persia to Central Asia.
cautions: May cause heartburn in sensitive individuals.

preparation: Short-time decoction of dried peel; taken with ORS as needed.
tradition_notes: Traditional astringent tea for acute, non-bloody diarrhea.
cautions: Short-term use only; constipation possible; do not replace ORS.

preparation: Light infusion or chewed seeds after meals.
tradition_notes: Common Central Asian spice used for post-prandial gas and bloating.
cautions: May aggravate reflux in some; evidence limited.

preparation: Infusion rich in vitamin C taken during colds.
tradition_notes: Widespread in Central Asia/Eastern Europe for winter colds.
cautions: High-acid tea may affect teeth; evidence for colds mixed.

preparation: Syrup or tea from young buds for cough/hoarseness.
tradition_notes: Traditional resinous expectorant in mountainous regions.
cautions: Resin allergies possible; avoid undiluted essential oil use.

preparation: Leaf decoction plus ORS as needed.
tradition_notes: Common across tropical Africa; used for infectious diarrhea support.
cautions: Does not replace ORS/antibiotics when indicated.

preparation: Slices boiled then sipped warm during colds/fever.
tradition_notes: Everyday kitchen remedy for febrile colds and chills.
cautions: Acidic; ginger may affect anticoagulants.
